awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Microbial conversion of pectin-rich agricultural waste into specialty chemicals
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is the development of yeast fermentation technologies that enable conversion of sugars abundant in pectin-rich agricultural waste into useful specialty chemicals. The U.S. is a leading producer of pectin-rich agricultural wastes including citrus peels (>5 million tons annually), sugar beets (>37 million tons annually), and grape pomace (>1 million tons annually). These peel and pulp byproducts lack value, however, the proposed technologies developed in this project will allow for significantly higher valued products to be produced from these waste streams. The initial target chemical product is used as a chelator in cleaning products and a precursor to plastics. Other chemical products potentially may be produced using this platform. Implementation of this fermentation process offers a lower carbon footprint and emissions compared to petroleum or even other sugar-derived products, and has impact in reducing waste and combating climate change. When implemented at scale, these fermentation processing plants will be co-located with rural agricultural processing plants, adding high-tech jobs in these areas, and offering a means to de-risk historically volatile crop harvests by accessing alternative markets.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to engineer yeast strains capable of converting sugars in pectin-rich agricultural wastes into valuable specialty chemicals. Currently, the fermentation rates for utilizing the primary sugar in pectin, D-galacturonic acid, limits production of these chemicals, including the proposed first product, which is a biodegradable metal chelator. Previous characterization has identified that uptake of the pectin sugars by a transporter as the limiting step. Accordingly, the first objective of this proposal is to characterize this class of transporter to identify new transporters with improved rates. The second objective is to improve the best transporter through protein engineering. Using this improved transporter, the final objective will assess the cellular energy requirements for the fermentation process using bioreactors to control fermenter conditions, as product synthesis and transport is energy-demanding. If successful, this project will enable production of specialty chemicals from pectin-rich agricultural waste.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is the development of yeast fermentation technologies that enable conversion of sugars abundant in pectin-rich agricultural waste into useful specialty chemicals. The U.S. is a leading producer of pectin-rich agricultural wastes including citrus peels (>5 million tons annually), sugar beets (>37 million tons annually), and grape pomace (>1 million tons annually). These peel and pulp byproducts lack value, however, the proposed technologies developed in this project will allow for significantly higher valued products to be produced from these waste streams. The initial target chemical product is used as a chelator in cleaning products and a precursor to plastics. Other chemical products may be produced using this platform. Implementation of this fermentation process offers a lower carbon footprint and emissions compared to petroleum or even other sugar-derived products, and has impact in reducing waste and combating climate change. When implemented at scale, these fermentation processing plants will be co-located with rural agricultural processing plants, adding high-tech jobs in these areas, and offering a means to de-risk historically volatile crop harvests by accessing alternative markets. 

This SBIR Phase I project proposed to engineer yeast strains capable of converting sugars in pectin-rich agricultural wastes into valuable specialty chemicals. Currently, the fermentation rates for utilizing the primary sugar in pectin, D-galacturonic acid, limits production of these chemicals, including the proposed first product, which is a biodegradable metal chelator. Over the course of this SBIR project, we performed extensive strain engineering, which included the use of a new yeast strain, and fermentation testing to improve production of our chelate product from D-galacturonic acid in this yeast. First, we identified a novel transporter from a microbe that can rapidly consume D-galacturonic acid and compared transporter homologs against know D-galacturonic acid sugar transporters. Second, we changed our production host to an acid-tolerant yeast and performed extensive tool development for this strain. Using these tools, we engineered our pathway into this new yeast host to improve product titers. Finally, we assessed the cellular energy requirements for this fermentation process. We found feeding of glucose to be crucial to ATP levels. Additionally, using bioreactors to control fermenter conditions, we determined oxygen feeding to be crucial to efficient product synthesis. The successful completion of this project has provided promising evidence in support of commercially-relevant production of specialty chemicals from pectin-rich agricultural waste through microbial conversions.

we performed extensive strain engineering, which included the use of a new yeast strain, and fermentation testing to improve production of galactaric acid from the galacturonic acid in this yeast. First, we identified a novel transporter from Rhodosporidium and tested transporter homologs against our leading sugar transporter, GatA. Second, we changed our production host to an acid- and thermo-tolerant yeast and through subsequent strain engineering improving titers 10-fold.

Last Modified: 07/24/2019
Modified by: Luke N Latimer

we performed extensive strain engineering, which included the use of a new yeast strain, and fermentation testing to improve production of galactaric acid from the galacturonic acid in this yeast. First, we identified a novel transporter from Rhodosporidium and tested transporter homologs against our leading sugar transporter, GatA.
